TEXT: The applicants are PERSON , who was born in DATE and lives at LOC , and Mr PERSON , who was born in DATE and lives at NORP - sous - Bois . Both are NORP nationals . They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

PERSON was the manager of a firm of general building contractors GPE ( “ GPE ” ) , a private company she had formed in DATE . Mr GPE , who was the managing director of a hotel complex , had business dealings with GPE and had awarded it contracts to fit out and decorate some of his hotels .
As a result of financial difficulties GPE was declared insolvent on DATE .

By a judgment of DATE ORG , composed of PERSON , President , and PERSON and PERSON , made an order for the judicial reorganisation of GPE under the simplified procedure and appointed PERSON as the insolvency judge and PERSON as his substitute .

On DATE , after hearing the report of the insolvency judge , Mr Levêque , a differently constituted bench of ORG ordered the company ’s liquidation under the supervision of the court , renewed the appointments of the insolvency judge and the substitute insolvency judge and appointed a liquidator .
On DATE ORG made an order on its own initiative for an audit of the company ’s accounts .
On DATE it appointed PERSON as insolvency judge in place of PERSON .
On DATE the auditor appointed on CARDINAL DATE lodged his report .

On DATE the liquidator issued proceedings against ORG , in her capacity as de iure manager of the company , and against PERSON , as de facto manager , in which he sought a receivership order against them , a declaration that they were jointly and severally liable to pay the entire shortfall in the company ’s assets and a decision on whether they should be declared personally bankrupt .

The case was heard in ORG on DATE . The court was presided over by PERSON , assisted by CARDINAL wing members . The representative of ORG sought an order declaring the applicants personally bankrupt . The court reserved judgment and granted the parties permission to exchange notes to the court in deliberations and to adduce documentary evidence by DATE . The applicants sent various documents to the court on DATE .

Meanwhile , by an order of DATE the insolvency judge , Mr ORG , declared an application by PERSON for the liquidator ’s replacement inadmissible and refused to refer it to ORG , which was the sole body with jurisdiction to hear it .
By a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the applicants’ applications and made a receivership order against them . In that connection , it added :

“ And on the basis of the finding in the insolvency judge ’s report that reorganisation will only be ordered to protect undertakings and there is no prospect of recovery in the instant case , the court makes an order for the commencement of judicial liquidation proceedings against [ the applicants ] ... ”

ORG also made an order declaring the applicants personally bankrupt for DATE , and ruled that it was immediately enforceable pending appeal . The applicants and the company appealed against that judgment . In their submissions , the applicants complained inter alia of the insolvency judge ’s presence on the bench that had delivered the judgment .
By a judgment of DATE ORG upheld all the provisions of the judgment , noting inter alia :
“ ... the court heard the report of the insolvency judge from which it emerged that there were no prospects of recovery in the instant case ;
... there is no provision of the PERSON of DATE that prevents an insolvency judge from sitting on the bench that delivers judgment . ”

By a judgment of DATE ORG dismissed the applicants’ appeal on points of law , holding that the insolvency judge ’s presence on the bench that had made the order for the liquidation of the applicants’ assets did not contravene LAW , even though he had previously acted as the insolvency judge in the liquidation of the company .
Section CARDINAL of Law no . DATE of DATE on ORG provides :

“ At any stage of the [ judicial reorganisation or liquidation ] proceedings the court may make a personal bankruptcy order against any de iure or de facto manager , whether paid or unpaid , of a juristic person ... ”
LAW implementing decree , Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE , provides :
“ ... The court shall , after submission of the insolvency judge ’s report , decide all issues arising out of the judicial reorganisation or liquidation that are referred to it . ”
